properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.location: Baring, Big Desert, Boinka, Linga, Patchewollock, Torrita, Underbool, Walpeup
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Baring, Big Desert, Boinka, Linga, Patchewollock, Torrita, Underbool, Walpeup. 
  • The a bushfire that started South of Underbool is not yet under control. 
  • The spread of the bushfire has slowed for now, but the situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
  • It is safe to return to the area. Be aware of potential dangerous bushfire and tree hazards.
  • There is a relief centre open at Blackburn Park Farrell Street Ouyen.
The threat is reduced, but the situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
What you should do:  
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. 
  • Enact your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
  • If you have time, check your neighbours to see if they are monitoring conditions. 
  • Protect yourself and your family. 
Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. Remember to: 
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area or Relief Centre at Blackburn Park Farrell Street Ouyen.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.   

The next update is expected by 11/01/2026 10:30 am or as the situation changes.   

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires) 
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.   
Accessibility: 
  • The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. For information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.location: Cathkin, Caveat, Ghin Ghin, Highlands, Killingworth, Koriella, Molesworth, Yarck, Kanumbra, Whanregarwen
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is being issued for Cathkin, Caveat, Ghin Ghin, Highlands, Kanumbra, Killingworth, Koriella, Molesworth, Whanregarwen, Yarck.

  • There is a bushfire at Longwood that is out of control.  
  • A wind change that occurred on Friday 9th January caused the fire to change direction toward the east (towards Lake Eildon).
  • While fire behaviour has reduced, the fire is not contained and is still spreading. 
  • This fire is threatening homes and lives.
  • It is too dangerous to leave the area safely so you must take shelter now.
  • This Emergency Warning replaces the Emergency Warning issued at 11.11am. 
You are in danger and need to act immediately to survive.

The safest option is to take shelter indoors immediately. It is too late to leave.
What you should do:

Move indoors: 
  • Protect yourself by wearing long sleeves and trousers, made from pure cotton or wool. Wear leather boots.  
  • Bring your pets inside.  
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents and turn off cooling systems. 
  • You must take shelter before the fire arrives. The extreme heat is likely to kill you well before the flames reach you. 
  • Shelter in a room that has two exits, such as a door or window including one directly to the outside. It is important to be able to see outside so you know what is happening with the fire.
If your home catches on fire: 
  • Move away from the rooms that are on fire, closing doors behind you.
  • As soon as the bushfire has passed the house, or conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt. Staying inside a burning building will almost certainly end in death. 
  • It may still be too hot to remain outside, so you will need to seek shelter in another structure or last resort option.
If you cannot get indoors, last resort options include:
  • Shelter in the middle of a large open area like a ploughed paddock, football oval or sporting reserve.
  • Get into a large body of water like a dam, lake, river, the ocean or inground pool.
  • Try to protect yourself from the fire's heat.
If you are travelling: 
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the warning area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety. 
  • If you are currently driving slow down and turn on your headlights. Smoke will make it difficult to see.
If you are caught in fire in your car: 
  • Park off the road behind a solid structure to block the fire's heat or pull over to cleared area.
  • Try to position the car towards the approaching fire.
  • Turn on your hazard lights and headlights.
  • Close all windows. 
  • Turn off the air-conditioning and shut all the air vents. 
  • Turn your car engine off. 
  • Get down as low as possible below window level and cover up with a pure woollen blanket.
Impacts in your area: 
The following roads are closed: 
  • Maroondah Highway between Yea and Maindample  
  • Maroondah Highway and Devon Road  
  • Merton Euroa Road closed through to the Hume Freeway  
  • McMenaman Rd and Maroondah Highway   
  • Kobyboyn Road and Highlands Road   
  • Ghin Ghin Road and Goulburn Valley Highway 
  • Faithfull Road at Hume Freeway 
  • Goulburn Valley Highway and Whatton Place 
  • Tarcombe Road at Hume Freeway
Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 10/01/2026 09:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Karbethong, Lake View, Mallacoota, Wingan River
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Karbethong, Lake View, Mallacoota, Wingan River.
  • There are bushfires at Mallacoota - Lake Barracoota and Cape Howe that are not yet under control.
  • The Mallacoota - Lake Barracoota remains active and continues to travel from the east of Lake Barracoota towards Lake View.  Aircraft continue to attack this fire.
  • NSW aircraft are currently working to suppress the Cape Howe fire, successfully reducing its rate of spread.
There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do in these changeable conditions. 
What you should do: 
  • People camping and recreating in the Lakeview area should consider leaving the area. 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Smoke is visible from nearby communities and roads.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 11/01/2026 11:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

This Emergency Warning is being issued for Mitta Valley including Tallandoon, Eskdale, Mitta Mitta, Dartmouth and surrounds. 
  • There is a bushfire in the Tallangatta Valley. 
  • The bushfire is out of control.
  • Leave to Wodonga using the Omeo Highway to Lockharts Gap Road. 
  • There is a relief centre at Wodonga Racecourse which allows pets. 
  • This Emergency Warning replaces the Emergency Warning issued at 3:47pm. 
Fire conditions are changing and becoming more dynamic. Leaving immediately is the safest option, before conditions become too dangerous. 

Emergency services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay.

What you should do: 

Travel to: 
  • The home of family or friends that is away from the warning area.
  • When you leave remember to take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger.
In the car: 
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety.
  • Slow down and turn on your headlights. Smoke will make it difficult to see.
If you are unable to leave you should shelter indoors:
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents. Turn off cooling systems.
  • You must take shelter before the fire arrives. The extreme heat is likely to kill you well before the flames reach you.
  • Shelter in a room that has two exits, such as a door or window including one directly to the outside. It is important to be able to see outside so you know what is happening with the fire. 
  • If your home catches on fire and the conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt. 
If you cannot get indoors, other last resort options include:
  • Shelter in the middle of a large open area like a ploughed paddock, football oval or sporting reserve.
  • Get into a large body of water like a dam, lake, river, the ocean or inground pool.
  • Try to protect yourself from the fire's heat.
If you are caught in fire in your car:
  • Park behind a solid structure to block the fire's heat or pull over to cleared area.
  • Try to position the car towards the approaching fire.
  • Turn on your hazard lights and headlights.
  • Close all windows.
  • Turn off the air-conditioning and shut all the air vents.
  • Turn your car engine off.
  • Get down as low as possible below window level and cover up with a pure woollen blanket.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Trees can be extremely dangerous during a bushfire or high winds. Do not stand, park or travel in areas of fire affected trees.
  • Embers are starting small fires ahead of the main fire.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.location: Break O'Day, Buxton, Devlin Bridge, Flowerdale, Glenburn, Rubicon, Taggerty, Woodbourne, Thornton, Toolangi
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Break O'Day, Buxton, Devlin Bridge, Flowerdale, Glenburn, Rubicon, Taggerty, Thornton, Toolangi, Woodbourne. 
  •  It is Not Safe to Return to Break O'Day, Buxton, Devlin Bridge, Flowerdale, Glenburn, Rubicon, Taggerty, Thornton, Toolangi, Woodbourne. 
  • The bushfire at Longwood is not yet under control. 
  • The bushfire is travelling from Alexandra in an easterly direction.
  • This Watch and Act message replaces the Watch and Act issued at 10.40am.
If you left Break O'Day, Buxton, Devlin Bridge, Flowerdale, Glenburn, Rubicon, Taggerty, Thornton, Toolangi, Woodbourne it is Not Safe to Return. Be aware of potential dangerous bushfire and tree hazards.
What you should do:

If you have not already left: 
  • Stay where you are and avoid dangerous bushfire and tree hazards.
  • Check you have enough food, drinking water and medications - if you do not, phone Triple Zero (000) for assistance.
If you have already left: 
  • Do not return to your home until a Safe to Return notification is issued.
  • Register at a relief centre so your friends, family and authorities can be informed that you are safe.
  • Stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings .
Relief centres are open at:
  • Lilydale High School Basketball Stadium, 26 Hutchinson Street, Lilydale 
  • City of Whittlesea Civic Centre, 25 Ferres Blvd, South Morang
  • Whittlesea Showgrounds for large animals.
Impacts in your area:
Many roads are closed in the area, including sections of the Maroondah Highway and the Goulburn Valley Highway. Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for current road closures.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for East Natimuk, Grass Flat, Natimuk, Quantong, Vectis, Vectis East, Vectis South.
  • The fire in the Natimuk, Quantong and Vectis area is now contained.
  • Firefighters, Emergency Service vehicles including heavy machinery continue to work on the fire and have commenced hazardous tree assessments in Natimuk and rural areas of fire ground. 
  • Residents who have remained at their properties should stay alert for dangerous trees and avoid travel. Traffic management points are in place, if you leave the fire area you will not be able to return.
This Watch and Act message replaces the Watch and Act issued at 4.58pm Saturday 10th January 2026. 
Staying close to a building where you can shelter is the safest option, as conditions can change suddenly.

Continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do:
  • Monitor changes, including increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility that indicates the situation is changing. 
  • If you are away from home, do not return.
If the situation changes you will need to leave quickly. Plan to:
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area.
Emergency services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay.
Impacts in your area:
The following roads are closed

Wimmera Highway 
  • is closed from Horsham at Curran Road. 
  • at the Nhill-Harrow Road towards Natimuk. 

Natimuk Frances Road is closed at Gymbowen, with traffic diverted to Nhill.

  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures. 
  • NBN connected phone and internet services will not work during a power outage. You will not be able to call Triple Zero (000) using your home phone.
  • A relief Centre is open at the Horsham Town Hall, Pynsent Street Horsham. 

This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 11/01/2026 10:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:

properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Patchewollock, Yarto, Baring. 
  • The a bushfire that started at 23 Km South West of Patchewollock is not yet under control. 
  • The bushfire is travelling from Freeway Track towards Jim Bathgate Road. 
  • The spread of the bushfire has slowed for now, but the situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
  • A relief centre is open at Blackburn Park Farrell Street Ouyen.
The threat is reduced, but the situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
What you should do:  
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. 
  • Enact your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
  • If you have time, check your neighbours to see if they are monitoring conditions. 
  • Protect yourself and your family. 
Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. Remember to: 
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
Impacts in your area: 
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.location: Tallangatta Valley, Bullioh, Koetong, Shelley, Berrignama, Lucyvale and surrounds
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is being issued for Tallangatta Valley, Bullioh, Koetong, Shelley, Berrignama, Lucyvale and surrounds.

  • There is a bushfire 25Km West Of Walwa that is out of control.
  • Current wind direction is from the West which is slowly moving the fire in an Easterly direction. A south/southwesterly change is predicted throughout the night which may change the direction of the travel of the fire slowly in a North Easterly direction.
  • As it is too late to leave the area safely, you must stay close to shelter and monitor conditions throughout the night on VicEmergency website or download the app.
  • This Emergency Warning replaces the Emergency Warning issued at 6.34pm
If you are in danger, you need to act immediately to survive.

The safest option is to stay close to shelter. 
What you should do if you are in danger:

Move indoors: 
  • Protect yourself by wearing long sleeves and trousers, made from pure cotton or wool. Wear leather boots.  
  • Bring your pets inside.  
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents and turn off cooling systems. 
  • You must take shelter before the fire arrives. The extreme heat is likely to kill you well before the flames reach you. 
  • Shelter in a room that has two exits, such as a door or window including one directly to the outside. It is important to be able to see outside so you know what is happening with the fire.
If your home catches on fire: 
  • Move away from the rooms that are on fire, closing doors behind you.
  • As soon as the bushfire has passed the house, or conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt. Staying inside a burning building will almost certainly end in death. 
  • It may still be too hot to remain outside, so you will need to seek shelter in another structure or last resort option.
If you cannot get indoors, last resort options include:
  • Shelter in the middle of a large open area like a ploughed paddock, football oval or sporting reserve.
  • Get into a large body of water like a dam, lake, river, the ocean or inground pool.
  • Try to protect yourself from the fire's heat.
If you are travelling: 
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the warning area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety. 
  • If you are currently driving slow down and turn on your headlights. Smoke will make it difficult to see.
If you are caught in fire in your car: 
  • Park off the road behind a solid structure to block the fire's heat or pull over to cleared area.
  • Try to position the car towards the approaching fire.
  • Turn on your hazard lights and headlights.
  • Close all windows. 
  • Turn off the air-conditioning and shut all the air vents. 
  • Turn your car engine off. 
  • Get down as low as possible below window level and cover up with a pure woollen blanket.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Bushfires can generate extreme heat. Heat will kill you before the fire reaches you. 
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 11/01/2026 12:30 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

This Watch and Act message is being issued for Creighton, Creightons Creek, Euroa, Kithbrook, Locksley, Longwood, Longwood East, Pranjip, Sheans Creek.
  • There is a bushfire at Longwood that is not yet under control.
  • The fire is active near the Euroa-Mansfield Road on the North Eastern edge of the fire 
The situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. 
  • Enact your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
  • If you have time, check your neighbours to see if they are monitoring conditions. 
  • Protect yourself and your family.
Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. 
Remember to:
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area.
Impacts in your area:
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 10/01/2026 10:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires) 
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • For information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice is being issued for Barkers Creek, Harcourt.
  • As of 11:45am Saturday 10 January, the tap water at Harcourt is not safe to drink. 
  • This advice has been issued following the impact of the fires in Harcourt on Friday 9 January 2026. Water services have been unable to safely access a burst water main, which may have caused contaminants to enter the water supply network.
Tap water is not safe to drink in Harcourt. Boiling the tap water will not make it safe. 
What you should do: 
  • Do not drink tap water.
  • You should only drink bottled water. 
  • If you are unsure if the water is safe to drink, you should not drink it.
It is unsafe to use tap water for: 
  • Food preparation, cleaning food or preparing baby formula. 
  • Cleaning dishes or clothing.
  • Making ice, brushing teeth and preparing beverages.
Maintaining personal hygiene: 
  • It is important to stay clean. 
  • Use hand sanitiser after going to the bathroom and before you consume food. 
  • Use disposable baby wipe products that are not soap based without water to clean yourself. 
Impacts in your area: 
  • All residents are asked to not drink tap water until further notice
This message was issued by Department of Health.  

The next update is expected by 11/01/2026 04:00 pm or as the situation changes.   

Use multiple sources to stay informed:  
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter 
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.    
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.  
  • For information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact the National Relay Service and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Barkers Creek, Harcourt, Harcourt North, Ravenswood South, Sedgwick, Sutton Grange, Walmer. 
  • There is a grassfire that started at Fogartys Gap Road, Ravenswood South that is not yet under control. 
  • The spread of fire has slowed and is not travelling outside the current burn area, but this can change at any time and the situation is still dangerous. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
  • It is not safe to return.
  • The fire crossed Calder Highway, impacted Harcourt, and has impacted Mount Alexander and areas to the east.
  • A copy of the current Community Newsletter is available here  
  • This Watch and Act message replaces the Watch & Act issued at 1:16pm Saturday, 10 January 2026.
  • This will be the last message for today, 10 January 2026, unless the situation changes. 
The situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
What you should do:  
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. 
  • Enact your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
  • If you have time, check your neighbours to see if they are monitoring conditions. 
  • Protect yourself and your family. 
Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. Remember to: 
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area.
Impacts in your area: 
The following roads are closed:
  • Axe Creek/Patons Road, Axe Creek
  • Calder Highway/Calder Alternate, Ravenswood
  • Sutton Grange Road/Sedgwick Road, Sedgwick
  • Fogartys Gap Road - From Calder Freeway to Walmer Road
  • Downes Road/Midland Highway, Castlemaine
  • Sutton Grange-Redesdale Road/Racecourse Road, Redesdale
  • Bendigo-Sutton Grange Road/Blackfellows Gate Road, Elphinstone
  • Calder Freeway/Pollards Road, Elphinstone
  • Pyrenees Highway/Golden Point Road, Golden Point
  • Calder Freeway/Malmsbury East Road, Malmsbury

Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures. 

  • The fire has impacted communication towers on Mount Alexander which has impacted radio broadcasting and free to air TV. Phoenix FM (106.7) are now providing emergency broadcasting for the ABC.

  • Grassfires can generate extreme heat.
  • Grassfires can start and spread quickly, and are extremely dangerous.  
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 11/01/2026 09:00 am or as the situation changes.  

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Hotline on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.  
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is being issued for Carlisle River.

  • There is a bushfire at Carlisle River Valley that is out of control.
  • The bushfire is travelling from Trotters Lane, Carlisle River in a north-easterly direction towards Carlisle River and Escarpment Road. 
  • The fire started on Trotters Track west of Carlisle River.  
  • This fire is threatening homes and lives.
  • It is too late to leave the area safely so you must take shelter now.
You are in danger and need to act immediately to survive.

The safest option is to take shelter indoors immediately. It is too late to leave.

Leaving now would be deadly.
What you should do:

Move indoors: 
  • Protect yourself by wearing long sleeves and trousers, made from pure cotton or wool. Wear leather boots.  
  • Bring your pets inside.  
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents and turn off cooling systems. 
  • You must take shelter before the fire arrives. The extreme heat is likely to kill you well before the flames reach you. 
  • Shelter in a room that has two exits, such as a door or window including one directly to the outside. It is important to be able to see outside so you know what is happening with the fire.
If your home catches on fire: 
  • Move away from the rooms that are on fire, closing doors behind you.
  • As soon as the bushfire has passed the house, or conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt. Staying inside a burning building will almost certainly end in death. 
  • It may still be too hot to remain outside, so you will need to seek shelter in another structure or last resort option.
If you cannot get indoors, last resort options include:
  • Shelter in the middle of a large open area like a ploughed paddock, football oval or sporting reserve.
  • Get into a large body of water like a dam, lake, river, the ocean or inground pool.
  • Try to protect yourself from the fire's heat.
If you are travelling: 
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the warning area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety. 
  • If you are currently driving slow down and turn on your headlights. Smoke will make it difficult to see.
If you are caught in fire in your car: 
  • Park off the road behind a solid structure to block the fire's heat or pull over to cleared area.
  • Try to position the car towards the approaching fire.
  • Turn on your hazard lights and headlights.
  • Close all windows. 
  • Turn off the air-conditioning and shut all the air vents. 
  • Turn your car engine off. 
  • Get down as low as possible below window level and cover up with a pure woollen blanket.
Impacts in your area: 
  • The following roads are closed: Carlisle Road in the fire area. 
  • Trees can be extremely dangerous during a bushfire or high winds. Do not stand, park or travel in areas of fire affected trees. 
  • Trees can fall across roads and cause dangerous driving conditions. 
  • Bushfires can generate extreme heat. Heat will kill you before the fire reaches you. 
  • Embers are starting small fires ahead of the main fire.
  • Aircraft are operating in the area overnight.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 11/01/2026 02:50 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Castella, Kinglake, Kinglake Central, Kinglake East, Kinglake West, Pheasant Creek, Toolangi. 
  •  It is Not Safe to Return to Castella, Kinglake, Kinglake Central, Kinglake East, Kinglake West, Pheasant Creek, Toolangi. 
  • The bushfire at Longwood is not yet under control. 
  • This Watch and Act message replaces the Watch and Act issued at 11.03am.
If you left Castella, Kinglake, Kinglake Central, Kinglake East, Kinglake West, Pheasant Creek, Toolangi - it is Not Safe to Return. 
What you should do:
Do not enter this area because you will place yourself in danger.
If you have not already left: 
  • Stay where you are and avoid dangerous bushfire and tree hazards.
  • Check you have enough food, drinking water and medications - if you do not, phone Triple Zero (000) for assistance.
If you have already left: 
  • Do not return to your home until a Safe to Return notification is issued.
  • Register at a relief centre so your friends, family and authorities can be informed that you are safe.
  • Stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Relief centres are open at:
  • Lilydale High School Basketball Stadium, 26 Hutchinson Street, Lilydale 
  • City of Whittlesea Civic Centre, 25 Ferres Blvd, South Morang
  • Whittlesea Showgrounds for large animals
Impacts in your area:
Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority. 

The next update is expected by 11/01/2026 10:30 am or as the situation changes.

properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.location: Alexandra, Fawcett, Lake Eildon, Maintongoon, Devils River
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is being issued for Alexandra, Devils River, Fawcett, Lake Eildon, Maintongoon.

  • The Longwood bushfire is not yet under control.
  • A wind change on Friday 9th January caused the fire to change direction toward the east (towards Lake Eildon).
  • While fire behaviour has reduced, the fire is not contained and is still spreading. 
  • This fire is threatening homes and lives. It is too dangerous to leave the area safely so you must take shelter now .
  • It is too dangerous to leave the area safely so you must take shelter now.
  • This Emergency Warning replaces the Emergency Warning issued at 11.20am. 
You are in danger and need to act immediately to survive.
The safest option is to take shelter indoors immediately. It is too dangerous to leave.

What you should do:

Move indoors: 
  • Protect yourself by wearing long sleeves and trousers, made from pure cotton or wool. Wear leather boots.  
  • Bring your pets inside.  
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents and turn off cooling systems. 
  • You must take shelter before the fire arrives. The extreme heat is likely to kill you well before the flames reach you. 
  • Shelter in a room that has two exits, such as a door or window including one directly to the outside. It is important to be able to see outside so you know what is happening with the fire.
If your home catches on fire: 
  • Move away from the rooms that are on fire, closing doors behind you.
  • As soon as the bushfire has passed the house, or conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt. Staying inside a burning building will almost certainly end in death. 
  • It may still be too hot to remain outside, so you will need to seek shelter in another structure or last resort option.
If you cannot get indoors, last resort options include:
  • Shelter in the middle of a large open area like a ploughed paddock, football oval or sporting reserve.
  • Get into a large body of water like a dam, lake, river, the ocean or inground pool.
  • Try to protect yourself from the fire's heat.
If you are travelling: 
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the warning area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety. 
  • If you are currently driving slow down and turn on your headlights. Smoke will make it difficult to see.
If you are caught in fire in your car: 
  • Park off the road behind a solid structure to block the fire's heat or pull over to cleared area.
  • Try to position the car towards the approaching fire.
  • Turn on your hazard lights and headlights.
  • Close all windows. 
  • Turn off the air-conditioning and shut all the air vents. 
  • Turn your car engine off. 
  • Get down as low as possible below window level and cover up with a pure woollen blanket.
Impacts in your area: 
Many roads are closed in the area, including sections of the Maroondah Highway and the Goulburn Valley Highway. Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for current road closures.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 10/01/2026 09:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:

  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Carranballac, Streatham and the rural area of Skipton. 
  • It is Not Safe to Return to Carranballac, Streatham and the rural area of Skipton. 
  • Hazardous trees and fallen powerlines, pose a significant risk to residents attempting to return home.
  • A hazardous tree assessment team is working to re-open roads. 
  • Although fire activity has subsided in the Streatham area, emergency services are still operating within the area.
If you left Carranballac, Streatham and the rural area of Skipton, it is Not Safe to Return.
Be aware of potential dangerous bushfire and tree hazards.
What you should do:

If you have not already left: 
  • Stay where you are and avoid dangerous bushfire and tree hazards.
  • Check you have enough food, drinking water and medications - if you do not, phone Triple Zero (000) for assistance.
If you have already left: 
  • Do not return to your home until a Safe to Return notification is issued.
  • A relief centre is open at the Beaufort Library, 72 Neill Street, Beaufort from 10:00am to 5:00pm.
  • Register at a relief centre so your friends, family and authorities can be informed that you are safe.
  • Stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Impacts in your area:
  • The following roads are closed:
  • The Glenelg Highway is closed between: Eurambeen-Streatham Road, Streatham and Pittong-Lismore Road, Skipton. 
  • Stockyard Hill Road at Park Road in Beaufort.
  • Glenelg Highway at Lake Bolac.
  • Eurambeen-Streatham Road at Mt William Road.
  • Rossbridge-Streatham Road at Mortlake-Ararat Road, Rossbridge.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority. 

The next update is expected by 11/01/2026 09:20 am or as the situation changes. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility:

  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice is being issued for State of Victoria.
  • You will see or smell smoke in parts of Victoria.
  • The smoke is a result of a multiple bushfires and grassfires burning across various parts of the state.
  • Smoke and ash from fires in the landscape may drift to far-reaching areas away from the fires .
What you should do:
Your nose is an excellent smoke detector. If you can smell smoke, take the necessary precautions to protect your health. 
You can self-assess the air quality near you using https://www.epa.vic.gov.au/for-community/environmental-information/air-quality/smoke/smoke-your-health.
What you should do:

  • Your nose is an excellent smoke detector. If you can smell smoke, take the necessary precautions to protect your health. You can self-assess the air quality near you using: https://www.epa.vic.gov.au/for-community/environmental-information/air-quality/smoke/smoke-your-health.
Take action to reduce your exposure to smoke and protect your health: 
  • People more sensitive to smoke are those with a heart or lung condition, including asthma; people over the age of 65 years; infants and children; and pregnant women. 
  • If you are sensitive to smoke, limit prolonged or heavy physical activity. Where possible, try to stay indoors. 
  • If you have a heart or lung conditions, take your medication as prescribed by your doctor. 
  • If you are asthmatic, follow your asthma plan and carry reliever medication with you. 
  • For more information on smoke and your health, visit the Better Health Channel. If you are concerned about symptoms, call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024 or see your doctor. 
  • If you or anyone in your care has trouble breathing or tightness in the chest, call Triple Zero (000) for an ambulance.
Impacts in your area:
  • Road travel may be hazardous due to low visibility associated with smoke.
  • Signs may be in place to slow traffic. Obey all traffic signs and instructions from fire agency crews near the fire.
  • The current weather patterns are likely to result in haze accumulating in low-lying areas.
  • It will be smoky or hazy in your area. 
  • Environment Protection Authority is monitoring air quality in the area.
This message was issued by Environment Protection Authority.

The next update is expected by 11/01/2026 08:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:

  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact the National Relay Service and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is being issued for Nariel Valley, Cudgewa, Corryong, Towong, Thowgla Valley, Biggara and surrounds.

  • There is a bushfire at 25Km West Of Walwa that is out of control.
  • Current wind direction is from the West which is slowly moving the fire in an Easterly direction. A South/Southwesterly change is predicted throughout the night which may change the direction of travel slowly in a North Easterly direction. 
  • Conditions can become very dangerous and unpredictable. 
  • As it is too late to leave the area safely, you need to stay close to shelter and monitor conditions throughout the night on the VicEmergency website or download the app. 
  • This Emergency Warning replaces the Emergency Warning  issued at 6.34pm. 
If you are in danger, you need to act immediately to survive.

The safest option is to stay close to shelter.  
What you should do if you are in danger:

Move indoors: 
  • Protect yourself by wearing long sleeves and trousers, made from pure cotton or wool. Wear leather boots.  
  • Bring your pets inside.  
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents and turn off cooling systems. 
  • You must take shelter before the fire arrives. The extreme heat is likely to kill you well before the flames reach you. 
  • Shelter in a room that has two exits, such as a door or window including one directly to the outside. It is important to be able to see outside so you know what is happening with the fire.
If your home catches on fire: 
  • Move away from the rooms that are on fire, closing doors behind you.
  • As soon as the bushfire has passed the house, or conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt. Staying inside a burning building will almost certainly end in death. 
  • It may still be too hot to remain outside, so you will need to seek shelter in another structure or last resort option.
If you cannot get indoors, last resort options include:
  • Shelter in the middle of a large open area like a ploughed paddock, football oval or sporting reserve.
  • Get into a large body of water like a dam, lake, river, the ocean or inground pool.
  • Try to protect yourself from the fire's heat.
If you are travelling: 
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the warning area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety. 
  • If you are currently driving slow down and turn on your headlights. Smoke will make it difficult to see.
If you are caught in fire in your car: 
  • Park off the road behind a solid structure to block the fire's heat or pull over to cleared area.
  • Try to position the car towards the approaching fire.
  • Turn on your hazard lights and headlights.
  • Close all windows. 
  • Turn off the air-conditioning and shut all the air vents. 
  • Turn your car engine off. 
  • Get down as low as possible below window level and cover up with a pure woollen blanket.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Bushfires can generate extreme heat. Heat will kill you before the fire reaches you. 
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 11/01/2026 12:30 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Barjarg, Bonnie Doon, Creek Junction, Dry Creek, Maindample, Tallangallook, Too-rour. 
  •  It is Not Safe to Return to Barjarg, Bonnie Doon, Creek Junction, Dry Creek, Maindample, Tallangallook, Too-rour. 
  • There is a bushfire at Longwood that is not yet under control. 
  • The bushfire is travelling from Longwood in an easterly direction towards Bonnie Doon.
If you left Barjarg, Bonnie Doon, Creek Junction, Dry Creek, Maindample, Tallangallook or Too-rour it is Not Safe to Return. Be aware of potential dangerous bushfire and tree hazards.
What you should do:

If you have not already left: 
  • Stay where you are and avoid dangerous bushfire and tree hazards.
  • Check you have enough food, drinking water and medications - if you do not, phone Triple Zero (000) for assistance.
If you have already left: 
  • Do not return to your home until a Safe to Return notification is issued.
  • Register at a relief centre so your friends, family and authorities can be informed that you are safe.
  • Stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Relief centres are open at:
  • Lilydale High School Basketball Stadium, 26 Hutchinson Street, Lilydale 
  • City of Whittlesea Community Activity Centre, 57/61 Laurel Street, Whittlesea.
  • Whittlesea Showgrounds for large animals

Many roads are closed in the area, including sections of the Maroondah Highway and the Goulburn Valley Highway. 
Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for current road closures.

properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is being issued for Barongarook West, Irrewillipe, Irrewillipe East, Kawarren. 
  • There is a bushfire at Carlisle River that is out of control. 
  • The bushfire is travelling from Pipeline Road Carlisle River in a north-easterly direction towards Irrewillipie East. 
  • Firefighters have not been able to stop the fire. The fire has crossed Whitepeg Road and Blackbridge Road is moving towards private property in the Irrewillipie area.
  • This Emergency Warning replaces the Emergency Warning issued earlier today.
Leaving immediately is the safest option, before conditions become too dangerous. 

Emergency services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay.
What you should do: 

Travel to: 
  • The home of family or friends that is away from the warning area. 
  • When you leave remember to take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger.
In the car: 
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety.
  • Slow down and turn on your headlights. Smoke will make it difficult to see.
  • An Emergency Relief Centre has been set up at Colac Otway Performing Arts and Cultural, 95-97 Gellibrand St, Colac, for anyone displaced by the Otway fires.If you have large animals with you please attend Colac Showgrounds.If you have domestic animals with you please attend Colac Community Hub in Connor Street. 
If you are unable to leave you should shelter indoors:
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents. Turn off cooling systems.
  • You must take shelter before the fire arrives. The extreme heat is likely to kill you well before the flames reach you.
  • Shelter in a room that has two exits, such as a door or window including one directly to the outside. It is important to be able to see outside so you know what is happening with the fire. 
  • If your home catches on fire and the conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt. 
If you cannot get indoors, other last resort options include:
  • Shelter in the middle of a large open area like a ploughed paddock, football oval or sporting reserve.
  • Get into a large body of water like a dam, lake, river, the ocean or inground pool.
  • Try to protect yourself from the fire's heat.
If you are caught in fire in your car:
  • Park behind a solid structure to block the fire's heat or pull over to cleared area.
  • Try to position the car towards the approaching fire.
  • Turn on your hazard lights and headlights.
  • Close all windows.
  • Turn off the air-conditioning and shut all the air vents.
  • Turn your car engine off.
  • Get down as low as possible below window level and cover up with a pure woollen blanket.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
  • Aircraft will be operating in the area overnight.
This messages was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 11/01/2026 04:00 am or as the situation changes.

  • Try to protect yourself from the fire's heat.
If you are caught in fire in your car:
  • Park behind a solid structure to block the fire's heat or pull over to cleared area.
  • Try to position the car towards the approaching fire.
  • Turn on your hazard lights and headlights.
  • Close all windows.
  • Turn off the air-conditioning and shut all the air vents.
  • Turn your car engine off.
  • Get down as low as possible below window level and cover up with a pure woollen blanket.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures. 
  • Aircraft will be operating in the area overnight.
This messages was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 11/01/2026 03:20 am or as the situation changes.

  • There is a bushfire at Carlisle River that is not yet under control.
  •  The bushfire is travelling from Trotters Lane in a north-easterly direction towards Pirron Yallock.
The situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. 
  • Enact your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
  • If you have time, check your neighbours to see if they are monitoring conditions. 
  • Protect yourself and your family.
Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. 
Remember to:
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area.
Impacts in your area:

properties.name: Emergency Warning
properties.location: Granya, Bungil, Burrowye, Walwa and surrounds
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is being issued for Granya, Bungil, Burrowye, Walwa and surrounds. 
  • There is a bushfire 25Km West Of Walwa that is out of control. 
  • Properties within the warning area could be impacted. 
  • Current wind direction is from the West which is creeping the fire in an Easterly direction. A South/Southwesterly change is predicted throughout the night which may change the direction of travel slowly in a North Easterly direction. 
  • Conditions can become very dangerous and unpredictable. 
  • A relief centre is available at the Wodonga Racecourse.
  • This Emergency Warning replaces the Emergency Warning issued at 5:19pm.
Leaving immediately is the safest option, before conditions become too dangerous. 

Emergency services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay.
What you should do: 

Travel to: 
  • The home of family or friends that is away from the warning area.
  • When you leave remember to take your pets, medications, a fully charged mobile phone and charger.
In the car: 
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety.
  • Slow down and turn on your headlights. Smoke will make it difficult to see.
If you are unable to leave you should shelter indoors:
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents. Turn off cooling systems.
  • You must take shelter before the fire arrives. The extreme heat is likely to kill you well before the flames reach you.
  • Shelter in a room that has two exits, such as a door or window including one directly to the outside. It is important to be able to see outside so you know what is happening with the fire. 
  • If your home catches on fire and the conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt. 
If you cannot get indoors, other last resort options include:
  • Shelter in the middle of a large open area like a ploughed paddock, football oval or sporting reserve.
  • Get into a large body of water like a dam, lake, river, the ocean or inground pool.
  • Try to protect yourself from the fire's heat.
If you are caught in fire in your car:
  • Park behind a solid structure to block the fire's heat or pull over to cleared area.
  • Try to position the car towards the approaching fire.
  • Turn on your hazard lights and headlights.
  • Close all windows.
  • Turn off the air-conditioning and shut all the air vents.
  • Turn your car engine off.
  • Get down as low as possible below window level and cover up with a pure woollen blanket.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Residents from Burrowye and Walwa should travel to Albury/Wodonga via NSW roads, which can be accessed at the river crossing on Jingellic Road.  
  • Residents from Thologolong and Granya should travel to Albury/Wodonga west along the Murray River Road.
  • For information on NSW fires click here
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This messages was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 11/01/2026 12:00 am or as the situation changes.

properties.location: Creightons Creek, Dropmore, Gobur, Gooram, Kanumbra, Kelvin View, Longwood East, Old Longwood, Ruffy, Tarcombe, Terip Terip, Upton Hill, Avenel, Caveat, Euroa, Highlands, Locksley, Longwood, Merton, Strathbogie, Whiteheads Creek, Yarck
properties.webBody:
This Emergency Warning is being issued for Avenel, Caveat, Creightons Creek, Dropmore, Euroa, Gobur, Gooram, Highlands, Kanumbra, Kelvin View, Locksley, Longwood, Longwood East, Merton, Old Longwood, Ruffy, Strathbogie, Tarcombe, Terip Terip, Upton Hill, Whiteheads Creek, Yarck.

  • This Emergency Warning replaces the Emergency Warning issued at 1.22pm on 10th January. 
  • Fire activity is increasing near the Euroa-Mansfield Road on the North-Eastern edge of the fire.
  • The Longwood fire is not yet under control.
  • This fire may threatening homes and lives.
  • It is too late to leave the area safely so you must take shelter now.
You are in danger and need to act immediately to survive.

The safest option is to take shelter indoors immediately. It is too late to leave.
What you should do:

Move indoors: 
  • Protect yourself by wearing long sleeves and trousers, made from pure cotton or wool. Wear leather boots.  
  • Bring your pets inside.  
  • Close all exterior doors, windows and vents and turn off cooling systems. 
  • You must take shelter before the fire arrives. The extreme heat is likely to kill you well before the flames reach you. 
  • Shelter in a room that has two exits, such as a door or window including one directly to the outside. It is important to be able to see outside so you know what is happening with the fire.
If your home catches on fire: 
  • Move away from the rooms that are on fire, closing doors behind you.
  • As soon as the bushfire has passed the house, or conditions inside become unbearable, you need to get out and go to an area that has already been burnt. Staying inside a burning building will almost certainly end in death. 
  • It may still be too hot to remain outside, so you will need to seek shelter in another structure or last resort option.
If you cannot get indoors, last resort options include:
  • Shelter in the middle of a large open area like a ploughed paddock, football oval or sporting reserve.
  • Get into a large body of water like a dam, lake, river, the ocean or inground pool.
  • Try to protect yourself from the fire's heat.
If you are travelling: 
  • If you are travelling, do not enter the warning area. Make a u-turn and travel to safety. 
  • If you are currently driving slow down and turn on your headlights. Smoke will make it difficult to see.
If you are caught in fire in your car: 
  • Park off the road behind a solid structure to block the fire's heat or pull over to cleared area.
  • Try to position the car towards the approaching fire.
  • Turn on your hazard lights and headlights.
  • Close all windows. 
  • Turn off the air-conditioning and shut all the air vents. 
  • Turn your car engine off. 
  • Get down as low as possible below window level and cover up with a pure woollen blanket.
Impacts in your area: 
Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.

There are Emergency Relief Centres operating: 
  • Seymour Sports and Aquatics Centre, (Chittick Park) Pollard St, Seymour 
  • Benalla Town Hall, 82-86 Nunn Street, Benalla
  • Mansfield Sporting Complex, 35 Highett Street, Mansfield
To register that you are safe or for enquiries regarding residents in the fire area go online to Register Find Reunite https://register.redcross.org.au/
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 10/01/2026 10:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

This Advice message is being issued in relation to the grassfire at Skipton. 
  • It is Safe to Return for people who evacuated from Skipton.

The following roads are closed;
  • The Glenelg Highway is closed between: Eurambeen-Streatham Road, Streatham and Pittong-Lismore Road, Skipton. 
  • Stockyard Hill Road at Park Road in Beaufort.
  • Glenelg Highway at Lake Bolac.

  • Rossbridge-Streatham Road at Mortlake-Ararat Road, Rossbridge.
A Watch and Act - Not Safe to Return has been issued to residents outside the township boundary of Skipton in the fire affected area.
It is now safe for you to return to your home or business.
What you should do: 
  • Stay alert - be aware of hazards caused by the fire. 
  • Be aware of road hazards such as fallen trees. 
  • Check your home or building for damage before you enter.
Impacts in your area:  
  • Emergency vehicles will remain in the area.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.action: Monitor Conditions As They Are Changing
properties.location: Georges Creek, Jarvis Creek, Bethanga, Old Tallangatta, Noorongong, Tallangatta and surrounds
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Georges Creek, Jarvis Creek, Bethanga, Old Tallangatta, Noorongong, Tallangatta and surrounds.
  • There is a bushfire 25Km West Of Walwa that is not yet under control.
  • Firefighters have not been able to stop the fire. The situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
  • The Murray Valley Highway is closed at the Lake Road intersection. 
  • You will be able to utilise the bridge at Old Tallangatta, but you should consider your alternate routes. 
  • A relief centre is open at Wodonga Racecourse. 
The situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. 
  • Have more than one way to get emergency Information. Mobile phone networks, internet service and electricity supply may be disrupted or unavailable. Have back-up ways to receive warnings such as listening to the radio, checking community notice points or following instructions from emergency services on the ground.
  • Enact your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
  • If you have time, check your neighbours to see if they are monitoring conditions. 
  • Protect yourself and your family.
Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. 
Remember to:
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area or to the relief centres above. 
Impacts in your area:
  • Bushfires can start spot fires and embers can travel large distances ahead of the main fire.
  • Bushfires can spread quickly and are extremely dangerous.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 11/01/2026 07:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for water pollution at Longwood.

  • The Longwood fire has impacted the operations of the Longwood Water Treatment Plant and this has impacted water supply to customers. 
  • Water is being brought into local storage tanks, which is now supplying the town. 
This advice has been issued as a precautionary measure. Customers should boil water prior to drinking, preparing beverages, washing and preparing food, preparing baby formula, brushing teeth and making ice. 


To ensure water is safe for consumption:
  • Heat water until a continuous and rapid stream of air-bubbles is produced from the bottom of a pan or kettle (kettles with automatic shut-off switches are suitable).
  • Allow water to cool before use.
  • Store water in a clean, closed container for later use.
  • Caution should be taken to prevent scalding from boiling water.

  • Consumption of unboiled water may lead to diarrhoea, cramps, headaches or other gastro-like symptoms.
  • If you are concerned please contact your local doctor and advise them of this notice. Infants, children, pregnant women, the elderly and immuno-compromised people are particularly at risk. 

  • Drinking water is available - a tanker of treated water that is safe to drink can be accessed between 8am and 4pm daily and bottled water is available 24 hours a day at the Longwood Recreation Reserve. 
  • Bring containers to fill from the tanker.


This message was issued by Environment Protection Authority.

Unless the situation changes, this will be the last message issued for this incident.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.

  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact the National Relay Service and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Angusvale, Cobbannah, Iguana Creek, Jones, Marthavale, Merrijig, Ryans, Selwyn, Tabberabbera, The Swamp, Wentworth, White Timber, Wongungarra. 
  • It is strongly recommended you Prepare to Leave. 
  • There is a bushfire at Mt Darling - Cynthia Range (Dargo Complex). The bushfire is not yet under control.
  • The bushfire is travelling from Wentworth Dargo Divide in a south-easterly direction towards the warning area. 
  • Embers may start small fires ahead of the main fire.
  • This Watch and Act message replaces the Watch and Act message issued at 5:58pm.
Prepare to Leave immediately. Leave as soon as you are ready, as roads will become busy as people leave.
What you should do:
  • Tourists and visitors are advised to pack quickly and leave the area immediately. 
  • Monitor the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can mean the situation is worsening.
  • Protect yourself and your family.
  • If you are not prepared, leave now. Dont wait until it is too late - leave early. 
  • If you are away from home, do not return.
If you are leaving, pack: 
  • Cash 
  • Clothing for three days 
  • Medicine for three days 
  • Phone and chargers 
  • Toiletries 
  • Important documents 
  • Meaningful items and photos 
  • Pet essentials, including leash and carriers.
Check on your neighbours if it is safe.

Check the VicTraffic website for road closures.

Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. 

Where to go:
  • Friends or family away from the fire. 
  • Consider roads may become busy closer to the time of impact. 

Impacts in your area: 
  • Trees can fall across roads and cause dangerous driving conditions.
  • Bushfires can spread quickly and are extremely dangerous.
  • Bushfires can start spot fires and embers can travel large distances ahead of the main fire.
The following Parks/Areas are closed to the public: 
  • Blue Pool on Freestone Creek Road is Closed. 
  • The Alpine National Park north of Briagolong, East of Arbuckle Junction and Mount Howitt, west of Dargo including the Wonnangatta, and south of Abbeyard, west of the Great Alpine Rd to Lake Cobbler is Closed. 
  • The Mitchell River National Park is Closed
Community Meeting: 
  • A community meeting will be held at the Dargo Public Hall and Recreation Reserve - 177 Lind Avenue Dargo Vic 3862 on Sunday 11th January 2026 at 11:00am. 

This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria. 

The next update is expected by 11/01/2026 12:00 pm or as the situation changes. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires) 
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

  • For information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
ADVICE - BUSHFIRE - Stay Informed
Incident Location: Colignan
Issue Date: Saturday 10 January 2026, 06:33 pm
Next Update: Sunday 11 January 2026, 11:00 am

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/39721/moreinfo

This Advice message is being issued for Colignan, Hattah, Kulkyne.
- There is a bushfire at Colignan that is not yet under control.
- The bushfire started from Brown Road Colignan and entered the Hattah Kulkyne National Park.


There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes.
